content_scrubbed:
My elementary school teacher was probably one of the biggest influences in my life. Mrs. Johnson was probably the person in elementary school that I felt closest to out of anyone. She recognized in me that I had a talent from a young age, and she offered me opportunities for special choirs, she helped me get songs ready to audition for theatre shows... she even re-wrote the 5th grade christmas program so that it was a play, and then she wrote me as the lead.

Then, as I got older, I got more and more involved in the arts. I auditioned for so many community theatre shows, I took music lessons, I learned how to write plays and books and stories.  Then, in high school, I was the presidents of 2 theatre student organizations. Hell, the mayor of the town appointed me as one of the city commissioners for allocating tax money for public arts.

Today, because of Mrs. Johnson, I am working my way through a college theatre program. I really don't know where I would be without her as an elementary school student.

She passed away a couple months ago. I live way out of state, so I didn't find out until my mom told me that it was in the newspapers. It[.] a weird thing to say, but I always wanted to be able to go back to my elementary school and tell her how much I appreciated everything she did for me. I just tell myself that she knew from the beginning, and that[.] why she put so much extra effort into teaching me music and theatre.

Damn, guess who[.] feeling glum now.
